fr.lipn.nlptools.utils.align
Class TokenIteratorInputReader

java.lang.Object
  fr.lipn.nlptools.utils.align.TokenIteratorInputReader
All Implemented Interfaces:
InputReader
public class TokenIteratorInputReader
extends java.lang.Object
implements InputReader

This InputReader reads tokens from an iterator over PositionedText objects. TODO As far as I remember the class has not been tested with the separator iterator.

Author:
moreau

Constructor Detail

TokenIteratorInputReader

public TokenIteratorInputReader(boolean ignoreCase,
                                java.util.Iterator<PositionedText> tokenIterator,
                                java.util.Iterator<PositionedText> separatorIterator,
                                boolean doNotCompareTokens,
                                char[] wildcardChars)
Detailed constructor

Parameters:
ignoreCase - Ignore case during token comparison (true by default)
tokenIterator - Iterator over the tokens (should match exactly the tokens sent by the AnnotatedTextReader, possibly ignoring case)
separatorIterator - if used, must contain exactly N+1 separators, where N is the number of tokens contained in tokenIterator. Set to null not to use.
doNotCompareTokens - Skip the comparison between the original (input) token and the one read by the annotated reader. This option should be used with caution: if set, the alignment between both sources is not controlled anymore (the only error that the aligner can catch in this case is when the number of tokens differ). This option is mainly proposed as a work-around in the case where errors are expected (originally due to a bug in TreeTagger, which has been corrected now).
wildcardChars - A set of characters that will be considered as wildcards, in the sense of the classical '?' regexp operator. In other words any char in this set will be allowed to match any other char, but only in the case where this 'wildcard' is read from the annotated text (matched against the original input text). This exception is introduced to skip cases where a character en/de-coding error happened: if the coding process was defined with a CodingErrorAction object to replace the faulty chars by some special char, then this char must be considered as a wildcard (otherwise the char from the original text will of course be different from the one read in the annotated text, though that was on purpose).

receiveTokenAndAnnotation

public void receiveTokenAndAnnotation(AlignerConsumer consumer,
                                      java.lang.String token,
                                      java.lang.String annotation)
                               throws AlignmentException
Caution: if position is between two different tokens (i.e. no token is given), sets end=end of previous token and start=start of next token That means that start>end in this case ! but consumer is supposed to receive something like <start annot><token><end annot>, so it is relevant (because a starting annot concerns the next token whereas an ending one concerns the previous one)

Specified by:
receiveTokenAndAnnotation in interface InputReader
token - the token read in the annotated text (may be empty or null)
annotation - the annotation related to the token (may be empty or null)
Throws:
AlignmentException

compareModuloWilcardChars

protected boolean compareModuloWilcardChars(java.lang.String token,
                                            java.lang.String originalToken)
Comparison taking 'wildcard chars' into account. Used only if the simple comparison fails.

Parameters:
token - the token read from the annotated text
originalToken - the token read from the original input text
Returns:
true if the strings match, false otherwise
